comment: Dry in flavor, has a tart finish that lingers on the pallate.
More like a 2.5. Has an ether off taste hidden by honey. Not the best to come from kilbeggan. Bit of spice and cask.

Very mild, very soft. Good mouthfeel. A hint of cereal makes its appearance midway through the first smell and the first sip. Not interesting enough for a regular dram, but great for mixes that call for Irish delicacy.
I wanted to love this whiskey, but it finishes too sour for me.
Meh. Nothing special. More hype than what it deserves, especially in Minnesota.
Great price, great flavor. Definitely pick this up to have on hand.

This is a very fine whiskey for a low cost. Goes down smooth neat and also mixes well with club soda and ice. Slightly sweet and very mild. It was $16 when I found it last year, now around $22.  It has replaced Jameson as my day-to-day Irish whiskey.
It has a funk on the finish that I'm not a fan of. It isn't terrible by any stretch but it is definitely not my favorite whiskey in this price range.
Unexpectedly smooth honestly.  Floral nose, some citrus late.  Not a ton of complexity, but still an enjoyable dram.
First time I had it as on a hot day at a Twins game. the second time was at Canterbury Horse track on another hot day. Otis the perfect summer refreshment. Love it!
Surprisingly tasty. Very scotchy to start, then changes directions toward something I wasn't sober enough to identify.
Very malty. May mix well, but not wonderful to my taste served neat or on the rocks.
Colleen tasted in flight.  Smoother than Jameson Black Barrel
Honestly very surprised by this, relatively smooth and not too spicy. Great deal for $17.99
Good mixer, but one-dimensional as a sipper.

Golden brown in color, it’s very likely that caramel color has been added to 2 Gingers so that it doesn’t look young and pale. The nose on 2 Gingers is a nice combination of fruits with apple, pear, and lemon combining with apricot and peach. Behind that are some pleasant sweet notes including caramel, vanilla, and honey, backed with a slight ginger spice. The entry for 2 Gingers is light and sweet featuring honey, caramel, malted barley, and green apple. Things transition quickly in the midpalate where 2 Gingers picks up some spice with black pepper, allspice, ginger, and a touch of eucalyptus. From there things get a little tart and acidic with the green apple re-emerging and combining with sour lemon for a fairly acidic and hot finish. The finish is of medium length, dry, and a little hot.
Really smooth. Definitely worth a buy
Sampled neat. Very good. Smoother than expected.

The second 50ml sample of the evening was generously supplied by a friend as part of a surprise Christmas gift.  This Irish whisky is only available in a few states in the upper mid-West:  2 Gingers.  It also comes in the standard 80 proof and is a clear, straw yellow in color.  Like most Irish whiskies it also appears to be very light.

The nose pops with a lively citrus and honey mixture.  There's a faint bit of oak if you really inhale it deeply, but it's very light.  On the palate it's a a tad sweet and malty.  There's nothing that jumps out at you through the entire sip.  A bit of a slight burn from the oak washes it away rather cleanly.  The finish is medium in length, warm but non-offending.

There's nothing outstanding about it when drinking it neat, but I could see it adding a bit of citrus to any mixed cocktail you choose to add it to.  I don't really drink mixed drinks using whiskey so I don't see myself needing a full bottle, but it was nice to review it neat and add it to my review catalog.  Cheers and thanks to Paul for the awesome Christmas gift.

Enters gently on the nose with malted, and almost toasted, barley notes as well as a little tart frutiness. Also, picking up hints reminiscent of a lightly peated scotch and grain/hay. Sits light on the palette. No burn, but a subtle warmth in the back of the throat along with notes of creamy barley. Finishes with an almost woodsy vanilla with latent spiciness. An excellent choice for the price.
Sweet, vanilla, not hot at all, comforting, and buttery. Light spiciness of ginger. Kinda similar to Glen Mornagie, though I don't get the fruitiness GM has. Maybe a hint of smoke?

Tart fruit on the nose for this fella; Granny Smith apples, white grapes, and shades of maltiness. More fruit on the palate, accompaned by cereal grains and the flavor and texture of warm honey. Finished with a creamy citric bite and a spiciness reminiscent of well... ginger. There. I said it.

Not the most compex dram in the world. But for $20, this is just right.
Deserves 3.5 stars but an excellent peaty Irish, less expensive than Bushmill's and better, excellent for $19.

This is my favorite in the $20 Irish price range. The nose has tart white winegrapes and sweet lemon pie, along with a touch of ethanol. It's got a very gentle body, too- caramelized pears, apples, and a touch of the characteristic copper. Higher proof would serve very well. Finishes short with mild dryness on the tongue. It's simple and pretty good, with more character than the competition. Albeit, not by too much.
Very smooth, sweet, and slightly buttery taste with a dash of smoked wood. Interesting and affordable but i find the lack of aftertaste a little disappointing
Lots of malt and honey, with a hint of wood towards the finish. Decent dram, but far from refined or complex.
Pretty good. I need to get more used to Irish before I judge it again
Unpretentious young Irish style blended Whiskey. Easy drinker that reminds me of a young Speyside blend. At $16.99 a bottle... pour it into whatever your heart desires. Cheers!
sample/definitely not worth 3 stars...Concannon superior at same cost.

The price was right to give this a try. Neat, I found the finish to be off-putting. The sourness is not often experienced in an Irish. 

I usually enjoy my whiskey neat or with a bit of ice, but will sometimes drink whiskey with Ginger Ale like me dear Granddad did. I found 2 Gingers was NOT a good companion, and mixing actually intensified the sour after taste.

For the sake of experimentation, I muddled 5 blueberries in with the same amount of whiskey and Ginger Ale, and that yielded a pleasant cocktail.
Fairly nice, Irish nose at first. Then it hits your tongue, and the tartness comes into play. Not my kind of whiskey.

For a go to shelf whiskey, this is the one I will always reach for. Everything you could ask for in a whiskey without any challenging notes or points of particular interest. This is a solid, everyday whiskey.
Good, but nothing to set this apart from other sweet whiskeys.  $20 is nice though.
Smooth and fairly sweet with a musk that tingles the nose.

Appearance: This Irish offering has a light straw gold color. And thick semi-watery legs make their journey back down the glass.

Nose: The nose first hits with a “grainy” nose more typical of blended Irish whiskies, but overall, sweet and full is the impression. Notes of sweet honey, lemon candy, milk chocolate malt balls, snickerdoodle cookies, red apples, and orange / cantaloupe parade across one’s nasal cavity.

Taste: On the palate the impression is also fruity and full with notes of orange, cherry, cinnamon, strawberry Twizzler candy, shortbread cookies, black tea with lemon, and red grapes. 

Finish: The finish is lingering with a Tannin-y and lemon rind flourish at the end.

Thoughts: Hey, for a budget Irish whiskey, this was not bad at all! It was complex, tasty, I liked it better after letting it open up a bit, but dang, for less than $25.00, I’ll recommend it! Thanks to both of you Gingers! Sláinte!

Found it for $15 and had to give it a try. I was very pleasantly surprised. Typical sweet caramel and vanilla for an Irish . Possibly a bit more spicy than some other Irish whiskeys. Definitely a lot more vanilla. I’d be interested to try with a coke, might make it a bit root beer-esque with all the vanilla. Overall great for the price. If you like Irish whiskey it won’t disappoint. I will say it has a bit of a sour aftertaste, so drink with caution, it will keep you sipping
Sweet honeyish taste with a nice mouth feel, short warm finish.

Miller/Bud light flavor profile; very thin, honey flavors known for Irish whiskys, but almost no wood notes. Non-peated Scotches have fuller flavor than this. Still a healthy warming feeling on the way down, though.
under $ 19.00 a good buy- a little burn

Took this from another review - not going to reinvent the wheel in this one. Good mixer!


"The nose is very light. I get some honey and malts. The taste is also pretty light. I saw someone else say butterscotch and I think it trends that way. Honestly for the price, it's a great budget Irish that I don't mind drinking neat. Nothing off-putting about it.”

Nose: Margarine
Palate: Oily Butter, slight Honey and Lemon; no Zest.
Finish Oil and then nothing. 

Thin AF. Smooth, but not a hint of complexity. Glad I didn't buy this bottle, but I might come back to it once.

*Finish: Little bit of coconut cream now on the 2nd dram
Pretty solid with a ginger ale

2 Gingers aint bad. Great with a cooler beer, makes a good flask whisky or a mixer. It’s super light and sweet, not much malt or pot still in the blend, but it’s also $15 out the door. After you’ve had enough of the good stuff and can’t tell anyway, this is the bottle you wanna find empty after doing shots at 4am! Not your Balvenie or Redbreast!
Highly enjoyable, especially with a drop of water. Caramel and toffee notes. The burn deeply drops off with just a little water added. Corn grits, apple skins. Resinous wood oils.

Nose of butterscotch and vanilla. Tastes of butterscotch, vanilla, orange and ginger but kind of tangy and sweet. A perplexing orange and ginger aftertaste that is kind of medicinal — quite can’t put a finger on it.  It is not your average Irish whiskey for certain.
Definitely not the best Irish, but not bad for the price.
Solid Irish whiskey. Smooth with a little burn when drinking straight or on the rocks. Even better when used as a mixer.

Nose- vanilla, dry metallic spice
Taste - light not oily, no spicyness maybe some carmel apple
Finish- quick, feel it more on the roof of my mouth, odd wetish cottonmouth feel

The nose is briny with honeyed notes in the finish.

On the palate, the whiskey is mild and smokey.  It finishes with brine in the mouth and just a little bite in the throat.  There is a pleasant aftertaste of cask wood.

I like this surprisingly well. Maybe it's just the power of suggestion, but I actually taste a little ginger. This is mild, but unlike other mild whiskeys this still has character. The finish is very nice. (There wasn't much nose.). For now this is my everyday.

Update: This gets better if you let it "breathe" for a few minutes.

Nose: light sweet honey/honeysuckle, maybe some shortbread, slight caramel, hint of vanilla, faint citrus that leans towards lemon. Taste: similar to nose, wood notes come in quickly afterwards, mild spice from the barrel, finishes with a light touch of bitterness. Not exactly what I’m looking for in an Irish whiskey but some may think it’s decent. I could see this mixing fairly well.
Smells great - initial taste great - finishes with a cheap burn!

Spicy citrus, potpourri; a prickly, spicy little number. Some butterscotch, toffee, oak, finished wood. All very pleasant and subdued. 

Would work great neat or on the rocks, and *super* affordable for those looking for quality on a budget.
Malt-focused nose with some prominent lemon notes on the palate. Remarkably mild overall
What a great but for such a fine Irish Whiskey! I'll be buying this again.

The nose is very light. I get some honey and malts. The taste is also pretty light. I saw someone else say butterscotch and I think it trends that way. Honestly for the price, it's a great budget Irish that I don't mind drinking neat. Nothing off-putting about it.
